SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: Massive 7.9 Earthquake In Nepal, KTM Shut?
I hope there is minimal loss of lives and damage to property in Nepal. Reports of multiple flights turning back - I'm guessing KTM airport is shut down.
#TravelUpdate: Kathmandu airport is closed. All operations in and out of Kathmandu have been suspended until further notice.
How will this affect the Turkish Airbus.
Does anyone know where on the airport it was stored?.
How will this affect the Turkish Airbus.
Does anyone know where on the airport it was stored?.
I don´t think it will suffer any more damage since it was at open air.
The airport is closed and all the communications are very difficult, so I guess the airport is a big mess right now, but I hope everybody is fine, that´s the most important part.
Nepal is not a very developed country but I guess they will get some help from India or China to re-store the normal situation as soon as possible.
A first Indian Air Force C130J has now landed at KTM.

Also, flight CZ3067 has left Guanzhou bound for KTM(<a href="http://www.flightradar24.com/CSN3067/61815c6" target="_blank">http://www.flightradar24.com/CSN3067/61815c6</a>). The aiport seems to be open and international relief flights will be able to arrive soon.
All my thoughts go to the nepalese people and my friends there.
A first Indian Air Force C130J has now landed at KTM.

Also, flight CZ3067 has left Guanzhou bound for KTM(<a href="http://www.flightradar24.com/CSN3067/61815c6" target="_blank">http://www.flightradar24.com/CSN3067/61815c6</a>). The aiport seems to be open and international relief flights will be able to arrive soon.
All my thoughts go to the nepalese people and my friends there.
I believe it was a C-17 Globemaster of IAF that reached KTM sometime back. Two more being loaded at Hindon.

Yikes - nearly 1000 killed per latest reports. Hoping for minimal further loss of life. Nepal seems like a beautiful country with great people (have had a chance to interact with some Nepalese immigrants in OKC). Would love to visit one day. Hopefully they can get the situation there under control as soon as possible.
Death toll keeps rising - now standing at 1500. Estimated total deaths of about 5000-7000, due to the sheer inaccessible nature of most of the mountainous region of Nepal.

Just in - Second relief aircraft IL-76, of IAF already on its way. First one will be returning with 52 people. All of the other transport a/c of IAF seems to be either on standby or enroute to Nepal with supplies.
Also in news - Huge avalanches have rocked the Himalayas and estimated hundreds killed and/or trapped. Most old towns in Kathmandu valley have been 'flattened'.
I recently spoke to friends in Kathmandu, and they are still experiencing aftershocks since past 5-6 hours.

Situation at KTM airport is airport closure except for relief flights. Some flights may take off after midnight depending on situation. People are trying to reach the airport from surrounding areas of the city/valley because of it higher ground.
Are their any other airports in India, close to Nepal, that could ultimately receive planes with aid?
According to the USGS ShakeMap, this one was no joke either! Kathmandu looks like it got a beating!
Are their any other airports in India, close to Nepal, that could ultimately receive planes with aid?
Planes with aid from foreign nations can land now. Pax operations are departure only for the moment, with arrivals resuming tomorrow, albeit quite delayed for sure.
Planes with aid from foreign nations can land now. Pax operations are departure only for the moment, with arrivals resuming tomorrow, albeit quite delayed for sure.
9W has tweeted that they are resuming services tomorrow.
How will this affect the Turkish Airbus.
Not sure that this would be the first thought that entered my mind when hearing of a massive earthquake in a underdeveloped, low-resource country, but to each his own I guess.

My thoughts and prayers are with all of those in Nepal, not least a colleague of mine & his brother who arrived in KTM last Saturday to climb to Everest base camp. Hoping that this is a case of no news is good news

The website himalayantimes.com is back up with news by district as it comes in. No specific information on the Kathmandu airport yet. Quite an achievement to get this news source back in business, given the total power outage in the city.
A Nepal Airlines 757 just took off from HKG headed to Kathmandu.
How will this affect the Turkish Airbus.

On the opposite side of the terminal apron.

My last picture post taken by me at KTM a month ago in TK KTM Crash Landing Video From Inside Cabin <a href="/aviation-forums/general_aviation/read.main/6362154" target="_blank">TK <acronym title="Kathmandu - Tribhuvan International (KTM / VNKT), Nepal">KTM</acronym> Crash Landing Video From Inside Cabin</a>
I wouldn't be surprised if they trash that airbus and/or crane it further away out of airport bounds for relief aircrafts and stuff, since TK doesn't seem to have done anything about it till now.
Strong aftershock (6.7) in Nepal. KTM seems to be closed again. Several flights are turning back:
FDB577 presently holding over southern Nepal
Seems like EY and QR planes returning to their base whilst another QR along with KA is holding over KTM for quite some time. In the meantime several aircraft took off including CA, TG 777 and TK 330.

My thoughts and prayers are with all of those in Nepal, not least a colleague of mine & his brother who arrived in KTM last Saturday to climb to Everest base camp. Hoping that this is a case of no news is good news

DItto, I also have a friend who is currently at Everest base camp. A member of his expedition has lost his life with others injured, I believe due to an avalanche that has hit base camp udring the quake, luckily they are not life threatening injuries. My good wishes to all in Nepal at this time.
<b><i>after Nepal earthquake, chaos at Katmandu airport: 'From Paradise to Hell' <i><b>...

<i>The runway was as busy as the passenger terminal. Soldiers in green fatigues scurried to unload supplies from a giant gray Indian air force C-17 Globemaster as the new traffic rolled in: a Sri Lankan military plane, a private jet, passenger planes from China, Saudi Arabia, Turkey and India.<i>
<i>Luggage handlers stacked their carts high with suitcases and bundles from flights arriving from New Delhi; Muscat, Oman; and Istanbul, Turkey.<i>
<i>The number of passengers hoping to depart far outnumbered those arriving, but the baggage claim hall was stuffed with a veritable United Nations of travelers.<i> ...

Seems like the KTM airport is under severe stress - I'm following the Indian flights to Nepal, they keep having to turn back due to a new aftershock causing the ATC services to shut down (due to the risk of collapse to the ATC building/ tower).
My post about the TK A330 was for two reasons;
1. That many of the obvious posts had been/would be made by others.
2. That this is an aviation site.

Seems like the KTM airport is under severe stress - I'm following the Indian flights to Nepal, they keep having to turn back due to a new aftershock causing the ATC services to shut down (due to the risk of collapse to the ATC building/ tower).

The priority will be given to military aircraft flying in relief/support/supplies. But there is also a balancing act to get passenger services in as it is important to start repatriating those currently stuck in Kathmandu. There will no doubt also be a backlog of people at Lukla who would ordinarily be flying back to KTM. Normally, in the case of weather delays at Lukla (starting point of most treks in the Everest region), those who require immediate departure could be ferried back to KTM via helicopter, but helicopter services are now no doubt concentrated on evacuating those injured at Everest Base camp + those in remote regions.

I forgot about Lukla. Does anyone know how it faired out? Judging by the Epicenter and the spread of the earthquake, I can't imagine some of the structures not collapsing on to the runway, if not the runway itself buckling. But, I'm being armchair with my opinion and I hope I am wrong.
I forgot about Lukla. Does anyone know how it faired out?
I'm hoping less impact on Lukla since it was away from the initial epicenter, although its been two days and we are still experiencing aftershocks since over 48 hrs...
are there any pictures available of the current situation of KTM airport?
Airbus are sending A350 MSN5 to KTM with medical aid.
Airbus are sending A350 MSN5 to KTM with medical aid.
AIB359 is being held up over KTM airspace, still waiting to get landing clearance. Could this be the first A350 landing in the Indian subcontinent?
